issues.title: Rename `mfa_token` to `mfa_code`?
issues.author: aaronpk
issues.body: The current `mfa_token` is more like an authorization code, in that it is relatively short lived, does not provide access to any resources directly, and is only used in order to obtain an access token. So maybe this should be called `mfa_code` instead?

issues.title: alternative_challenge_types i section 7.2
issues.author: PieterKas
issues.body:
Strong support for this.

Scenario: Present user with a default and list of alternative MFA methods.

issues.title: Password can only be passed on initiation of flow, not as a later prompt
issues.author: PieterKas
issues.body:
There is no option to present a password after the flow is initiated. Once the user has an MFA token, there is no way to prompt for a password. Some scenarios may need to prompt for a password after collecting say an OTP, or perhaps even and SMS code, depending on risk rules etc. 

Options to consider:

- drop “password” parameter from authorization-initiation endpoint.
- add challenge_type=password in 3.4, add 7.2.6 and 7.3.6 for “persistent/traditional password challenge” and interaction.

issues.title: Consider renaming MFA_token to Credential Token
issues.author: PieterKas
issues.body: Although we have a heavy emphasis on enabling MFA, sometimes MFA will not be used (or at least not immediately,  a step-up may follow much later). The outcome may still be MFA, but not always.

issues.title: Consider simplifying section 8 by removing distinction between mfa_otp and otp (for example)
issues.author: PieterKas
issues.body: Feedback from implementors was that it was not clear that these are truly different with suggestions that whether it is MFA or single factor being determined by the flow the AS performs.

issues.title: Consider adding "display_name" for each challenge_type
issues.author: PieterKas
issues.body:
Scenario: 

Users may have multiple out-of-band proofs on a single account, in two dimensions. Users can have an email, a phone number, and an authenticator app. And, users can also have multiple of any of these factors – multiple email addresses, multiple phone numbers, and authenticator apps on multiple devices. In the case of say, multiple phones for SMS codes, we need to be able to let them pick which one to use. One option is to add a "display_name" to the "challenge type" to help the end user select which one to pick.

issues.title: How to support phone number confirmation before sending a code?
issues.author: PieterKas
issues.body: When the user selects to send a text message, UI shows them their phone number as “XXX-XXX-AA34” and asks the user to provide the missing digits “AA”. Then, once the user indicates that the missing digits are e.g. “12”, the authorization server (Authorization Challenge Endpoint) sends the user the text message and asks them to enter the code.

issues.title: Consider adding support for consent collection as a "challenge_type"
issues.author: PieterKas
issues.body: The authorization server might interrupt a user who is currently signing in, show them their current auth methods, and ask them to confirm that these auth methods are still current, complete a captcha or confirm their age. Possible solution is a "challenge_type=user_prompt".

issues.title: Add clarification for why we need Authorization Initiation Endpoint
issues.author: PieterKas
issues.body: Could we get away with just using the regular token endpoint?

issues.title: Clarify how client compatibility may achieved
issues.author: PieterKas

issues.title: Consider how to prevent "redirect" challenge from being abused.
issues.author: PieterKas
issues.body:
The error=mfa_required, followed by challenge_type=redirect with some new context mechanism may be used by OAuth providers to switching to a web auth to show arbitrary prompts (like legal notices, notices of expiring billing information, etc.) In other words, they’ll use error=mfa_required/credential_required to show non-credential non-MFA prompts, contradictory to the error code. 

Is there an alternative we can propose (e.g. claims challenge type flow)?

issues.title: Provide hints to describe what kind of OOB mechanism is used
issues.author: PieterKas
issues.body: The native app would benefit from knowing if SMS, e-mail or an app is being used for the OOB flow. Perhaps there is an extra parameter that can be passed back as a hint to the UI?
